verses.text: Praise the LORD. Praise God in his sanctuary; praise him in his mighty heavens.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 150:1
rsbNotes.text:
150:1 Praise the Lord. See Ps. 146:1. Note the parallel closing at v. 6.

in his sanctuary . . . in his mighty heavens. These are the locations where worship was focused.

verses.text: Praise him for his acts of power; praise him for his surpassing greatness.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 150:2
rsbNotes.text: 150:2 his mighty deeds . . . his excellent greatness. This verse gives reasons why God should be worshiped.

verses.text: Praise him with the sounding of the trumpet, praise him with the harp and lyre,
praise him with tambourine and dancing, praise him with the strings and flute,
praise him with the clash of cymbals, praise him with resounding cymbals.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 150:3–5
rsbNotes.text: 150:3–5 trumpet . . . lute and harp . . . tambourine and dance . . . strings and pipe . . . cymbals. A wonderful array of instruments for the praises of God. See “Music in the Church” at Col. 3:16.

verses.text: Let everything that has breath praise the LORD. Praise the LORD.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 150:6
rsbNotes.text:
150:6 everything that has breath. See Gen. 2:7. Life is represented in the breath. The breath is also the means of speech, for prayer, and for praise.

Praise the Lord. See v. 1.
